description.en:
Introduction: evaluation, counterfactuals, causality; the Rubin model; R basics.
Difference-in-differences methods.
Coarsened exact matching.
Propensity score matching.
Inverse Probability Weighting and Regression Adjustment.
Regression Discontinuity Design.
Intrumental Variables.
Synthetic control.

objectives.en: The main objective of the course is that students are exposed to and are able to apply the most used methods to elicit and measure causal relationships in social phenomena.
objectives.et: The main objective of the course is that students are exposed to and are able to apply the most used methods to elicit and measure causal relationships in social phenomena.

learning_outcomes.en: Students learn (1) the main theoretical underpinnings and (2) the main technical aspects of the following methods: the Rubin model; difference-in-differences methods; coarsened exact matching; propensity score matching; RA, IPW and IPWRA; regression discontinuity design; instrumental variables; synthetic control.
learning_outcomes.et: Students learn (1) the main theoretical underpinnings and (2) the main technical aspects of the following methods: the Rubin model; difference-in-differences methods; coarsened exact matching; propensity score matching; RA, IPW and IPWRA; regression discontinuity design; instrumental variables; synthetic control.

learning_outcomes.en: Students are (3) able to choose the most appropriate from above for a particular dataset and research question.
learning_outcomes.et: Students are (3) able to choose the most appropriate from above for a particular dataset and research question.

learning_outcomes.en: Students (4) develop their critical thinking when reading and appraising a research paper.
learning_outcomes.et: Students (4) develop their critical thinking when reading and appraising a research paper.

learning_outcomes.en: Students are (5) able to write a code in R in order to (5.1) produce descriptive statistics, (5.2) run an econometric model and (5.3) test hypotheses.
learning_outcomes.et: Students are (5) able to write a code in R in order to (5.1) produce descriptive statistics, (5.2) run an econometric model and (5.3) test hypotheses.

learning_outcomes.en: Students (6) develop their ability to interpret (6.1) statistics, (6.2) output from econometric models and (6.3) the results from hypothesis tests.
learning_outcomes.et: Students (6) develop their ability to interpret (6.1) statistics, (6.2) output from econometric models and (6.3) the results from hypothesis tests.

learning_outcomes.en: Students (7) connect econometric practice with the social, economic, political and business reality.
learning_outcomes.et: Students (7) connect econometric practice with the social, economic, political and business reality.

independent_work.et: Five home individual assignments: one per week; exercises; theory; one referee report. Details given during the classes.

description.en: There will be five home exercises; each exercise will be assigned a letter grade (from A to F); the final grade is a simple mean of the home exercise grades.
description.et: There will be five home exercises; each exercise will be assigned a letter grade (from A to F); the final grade is a simple mean of the home exercise grades.

grade_evaluation.et: Final result depends on home assignments. Each gives 20%.

debt_elimination.et: Home exercies must be submitted to receive the final grade.
